Key Arguments: The legislation threatens freedom of opinion and expression, which are essential to a democratic society.
The government should not be the ultimate arbiter of truth, as this could lead to a dystopian society similar to those depicted in George Orwell's 1984 or in countries like North Korea and China.
The concepts of 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are subjective and open to interpretation.
The bill exempts government and mainstream media from its rules, which is seen as hypocritical.
The definition of harm in the bill is subjective and could be used to suppress free speech and enforce approved narratives.
Notable Quotes: With the government as the ultimate arbiter of truth, Australia would no longer be a democracy, but a model of the dystopian 'Ministry of Truth' from George Orwell's 1984.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from this censorship regime is blatantly hypocritical.
This Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication.
